unnormalised: The year was 2030. Paper documents were relics of the past. Everything was digital, integrated, and supposedly seamless. My grandmother, Nirmala Devi, however, wasn't buying it. At 80 yrs old, she clung to her physical Aadhaar card like a lifeline, refusing to get an updated digital version. “These computers can fail beta,” she’d say, adjusting her spectacles. “This old card, number 2468-1357-9012, is my proof.”
normalised: The year was two thousand and thirty. Paper documents were relics of the past. Everything was digital, integrated, and supposedly seamless. My grandmother, Nirmala Devi, however, wasn't buying it. At eighty years old, she clung to her physical Aadhaar card like a lifeline, refusing to get an updated digital version. “These computers can fail beta,” she’d say, adjusting her spectacles. “This old card, number two four six eight dash one three five seven dash nine zero one two, is my proof.”

unnormalised: Her stubbornness became a problem when she needed to claim her pension. The bank, SBI, insisted on verifying her identity through the new e-KYC system, requiring a digital scan of her PAN card (ABCDE1234F) and linking it to her Aadhaar. My mom tried explaining patiently. But Nirmala ji just folded her arms, declaring the process too complicated. She would prefer waiting in a queue, she said.
normalised: Her stubbornness became a problem when she needed to claim her pension. The bank, S-B-I, insisted on verifying her identity through the new e-K-Y-C system, requiring a digital scan of her P-A-N card (A-B-C-D-E one two three four F) and linking it to her Aadhaar. My mom tried explaining patiently. But Nirmala ji just folded her arms, declaring the process too complicated. She would prefer waiting in a queue, she said.

unnormalised: I stepped in, promising to navigate the online portals. First hurdle: her digital Aadhaar wasn't linked to her current mobile number. The old number registered was +919876543210, used when she lived in Patna. After several calls to UIDAI helpline and numerous OTPs, we managed to update it. I thought we had cracked the process.
normalised: I stepped in, promising to navigate the online portals. First hurdle: her digital Aadhaar wasn't linked to her current mobile number. The old number registered was plus ninety one nine eight seven six five four three two one zero, used when she lived in Patna. After several calls to U-I-D-A-I helpline and numerous O-T-P-s, we managed to update it. I thought we had cracked the process.

unnormalised: Then came the PAN verification. Turns out, her PAN details weren’t properly synced with the Aadhaar database, citing a mismatch in her date of birth – 15/08/1950, as per Aadhaar, vs. 16/08/1950, on her PAN. Cue another round of government websites, form submissions, and frustrating waiting times. I realised, this digital revolution often left those unfamiliar with tech behind.
normalised: Then came the P-A-N verification. Turns out, her P-A-N details weren’t properly synced with the Aadhaar database, citing a mismatch in her date of birth – fifteenth August nineteen fifty, as per Aadhaar, versus sixteenth August nineteen fifty, on her P-A-N. Cue another round of government websites, form submissions, and frustrating waiting times. I realised, this digital revolution often left those unfamiliar with tech behind.

unnormalised: Finally, after a week of paperwork and online wrangling, Nirmala Devi’s e-KYC was completed. She received a confirmation SMS. "See, beta," she said, holding up her laminated Aadhaar card, "this old thing still works just fine. And it never needs an internet connection." Maybe she was right. Maybe some things are better left in their original form.
